{{Infobox magazine | title = Skeptic | image_file = Skeptic-1.jpg | image_size = 200px | image_caption = Premiere issue of ''Skeptic'',
featuring a tribute to [[Isaac Asimov]]. | editor = [[Michael Shermer]] | editor_title = Editor-in-Chief | frequency = Quarterly | circulation = 50,000 subscribers{{cite web |url=http://www.skeptic.com/the_magazine/contribute.html |title=Contribution Guidelines|newspaper=Skeptic|accessdate=March 5, 2015}} | category = [[List of skeptical magazines|Skeptical magazine]] | company = Millennium Press | publisher = [[The Skeptics Society]] | firstdate = Spring 1992 | country = United States | based = Altadena, California | language = [[English language|English]] | website = [http://www.skeptic.com/ www.Skeptic.com] | issn = 1063-9330 }} '''''Skeptic''''', colloquially known as '''''Skeptic magazine''''', is a quarterly [[science education]] and science advocacy [[magazine]] published internationally by [[The Skeptics Society]], a [[nonprofit]] organization devoted to promoting [[scientific skepticism]] and resisting the spread of [[pseudoscience]], [[superstition]], and [[irrationality|irrational]] beliefs.{{cite web |url=http://www.skeptic.com/about_us/what_we_do/ |title=What We Do |author= |date= |website= |publisher=Skeptic (U.S. magazine) |access-date=March 5, 2015 |quote=}} Founded by [[Michael Shermer]], founder of the Skeptics Society,[http://www.skeptic.com/about_us/meet_michael_shermer.html "Meet Michael Shermer"]. ''Skeptic''. Retrieved March 5, 2015. the magazine was first published in the spring of 1992 and is published through Millennium Press. Shermer remains the Publisher and [[Editor-in-Chief]] of the magazine and the magazine’s Co-publisher and [[Art Director]] is Pat Linse.{{cite web |url=http://www.skeptic.com/the_magazine/masthead.html |title=Masthead, ''Skeptic'' Magazine. |accessdate=1 December 2008}} Other noteworthy members of its editorial board include, or have included, [[Oxford University]] [[evolutionary biology|evolutionary biologist]] [[Richard Dawkins]], [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning scientist [[Jared Diamond]], [[Magician (illusion)|magician]] and [[escape artist]] turned educator [[James Randi|James “The Amazing” Randi]], actor, comedian, and ''[[Saturday Night Live]] '' alumna [[Julia Sweeney]], professional mentalist [[Mark Edward]], science writer [[Daniel Loxton]], [[Lawrence M. Krauss]] and [[Christof Koch]]. ''Skeptic'' has an international circulation with over 50,000 subscriptions and is on newsstands in the U.S. and Canada as well as Europe, Australia, and other countries.{{cite news | url=http://www.vueweekly.com/making_a_living_of_bullshit_detecting/ | title=Making a living of bullshit detecting | publisher=[[VUE Weekly]] |date=August 27, 2008 | first= | last= | accessdate =2008-10-10 }} == History, format and structure == The cover story of the magazine's very first issue paid tribute to [[scientist]] and [[science-fiction]] writer [[Isaac Asimov]]. [http://shop.skeptic.com/merchant.mvc?&Screen=PROD&Store_Code=SS&Product_Code=magv01n1&Category_Code=BIA "Vol. 1 No.1 (Premiere Issue) Tribute to Isaac Asimov"]. ''Skeptic''. Retrieved March 5, 2015. As Asimov wrote a number of stories featuring robots and coined the term "[[robotics]]", the cover of volume 12, #2 (2006), which is devoted to the topic of artificial intelligence, depicts a [[robot]] sitting on a park bench reading that first issue.[http://shop.skeptic.com/merchant.mvc?&Screen=PROD&Store_Code=SS&Product_Code=magv12n2 "Vol. 12 No. 2 Artificial Intelligence"]. ''Skeptic''. Retrieved March 5, 2015. Every issue of the magazine opens with a description of The Skeptics Society and its mission statement, which is to explore subjects such as [[creationism]], [[pyramid power]], [[Bigfoot]], [[pseudohistory|pseudohistorical claims]] (as in the examples of [[Holocaust denial]] and extreme [[Afrocentrism]]), the use or misuse of theory and [[statistics]], [[conspiracy theories]], [[urban myths]], [[witch-hunt]]s, [[mass hysterias]], [[genius]] and [[intelligence]], and cultural influences on science, as well as controversies involving [[protoscience]]s at the leading edge of established science, and even [[fads]] like [[cryonics]] and [[low-carb diet]]s. In addition to publishing the magazine, the Society also: * sponsors lecture series at the [[California Institute of Technology]] * produces and sells tapes of the lectures, as well as other books on pertinent subjects * holds field trips to investigate and research such subjects * conducts social events to promote good-will * provides resources for the public, skeptic organizations (such as [[SkeptiCamp]]{{cite web | url=http://www.skepticamp.org | title=Skepticamp | accessdate =2012-03-21}}) and the media, with which they may approach controversial subjects from a skeptical viewpoint In 2011, the magazine had three regular columnists: [[James Randi]] wrote "’Twas Brillig…," [[Harriet A. Hall]] wrote "The Skep Doc" and [[Karen Stollznow]] wrote "Bad Language".{{Cite news | title=Table of Contents | magazine=Skeptic | publisher=Skeptics Society | url=http://www.skeptic.com/the_magazine/archives/vol16n02.html | volume=16 | issue=2 | accessdate=July 10, 2011 }} The magazine's page count was between approximately 100 and 110 pages until the 2010s. It was reduced to approximately 80 pages with Vol. 16 No. 3 (2011).{{CN|date=March 2018}} {{As of |2018}}, the magazine had two regular columnists: Harriet A. Hall and [[Carol Tavris]].{{cite web|title=Skeptic: CURRENT ISSUE: VOLUME 23 NUMBER 1|url=https://www.skeptic.com/magazine/|website=skeptic.com|publisher=Skeptic Magazine|accessdate=30 March 2018|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180330232530/https://www.skeptic.com/magazine/|archivedate=30 March 2018|df=}} === Typical topics === Each issue features an [[editorial]]. In the past this was provided by [[James Randi]], and was often a reaction to stories from mainstream news media such as the 2005 story by the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] [[newsmagazine]] ''[[Primetime Live]]'' featuring a [[Brazil]]ian [[faith healer]], [[João de Deus (medium)|João Teixeira]].{{CN|date=March 2018}} Other times Randi wrote about topics he had investigated in the past, such as alleged [[dowser]]s,{{cite web|url=https://www.skeptic.com/eskeptic/11-08-31/#feature/|title = A Report from the Paranormal Trenches|website=Skeptic.com|publisher=Skeptic Magazine|accessdate=30 March 2018|date = 2011-08-31}} alleged [[psychic]]s like [[Sylvia Browne]], and UFOs.{{CN|date=March 2018}} The magazine also features a large correspondence section called "Forum". This includes not only letters from lay readers but also in-depth comments and rebuttals from [[professional]]s, contributing to extended academic debate across issues raised in past editions.{{CN|date=March 2018}} The bulk of the magazine treats a variety of topics. [[Front cover|Cover stories]] have ranged from examination of alleged [[UFO]]s in [[religious icons]] and theories of the likelihood of [[artificial intelligence]] to tributes to luminaries such as [[Isaac Asimov]] and [[Ernst Mayr]].[[Sulloway, Frank J.]] (February 2005). [http://www.skeptic.com/eskeptic/05-02-11/ "Ernst Mayr, 1904–2005Remembrances & Tribute"]. ''Skeptic''. {{my|ဝိမလ}} |birth_date = {{Birth date|1899|12|27|df=y}} |birth_place = Uyindaw Village, [[Mandalay Division|Mandalay Province]], [[Burma]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|1962|10|17|1899|12|27|df=y}} |death_place = [[Amarapura]], [[Mandalay Division]], Burma |nationality = Myanmar |religion = [[Buddhism]] |school = [[Theravada]] |lineage = |title = [[Agga Maha Pandita]] |location = Mogok Monastery, [[Amarapura]], Burma |education = |occupation = [[bhikkhu]] |teacher = |predecessor = |successor = |students = |website = }} {{Burmese name|U}} '''U Vimala''' ({{lang-my|မိုးကုတ်ဆရာတော် ဦးဝိမလ}}, commonly known as the '''Mogok Sayadaw'''; 27 December 1899 - 17 October 1962) was a renowned [[bhikkhu]] and [[vipassanā]] meditation master of [[Theravada|Theravada Buddhism]].{{cite book|last=Aung Chi|title=The Mogok Sayadaw: A Translation|location=Yangon|date=2000}} ==Early life== [[File:Mogok Sayadaw.jpg|thumb|Mogok Sayadaw seated.]] He was born [[Burmese names|Maung]] Hla Baw to Daw Shwe Ake and U Aung Tun in a small village close to [[Amarapura]] in Mandalay Province, Burma on 27 December 1899.{{cite web|url=http://www.thisismyanmar.com/nibbana/mogokst1.htm |title=The Mogok Sayadaw |last=Sway Tin |date=15 November 1999 |work=Nibbana.com |accessdate=23 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120927024942/http://www.thisismyanmar.com/nibbana/mogokst1.htm |archivedate=September 27, 2012 }} Hla Baw began his education at 4, and enrolled as a [[Śrāmaṇera|samanera]] or novitiate at age 9 under U Jagara. He later left for Mingala Makuna Monastery at Amarapura to continue his religious studies. ==Monkhood== In 1920, he was ordained as a [[bhikkhu]] (monk) in the tradition of [[Buddhism in Burma|Burmese Buddhism]] with the [[dharma name]] Vimala ({{my|ဝိမလ}}) which means "stainless, Undefiled." As his monkhood was sponsored by the residents of [[Mogok]], a town well known for rubies and gems, Vimala became known as "Mogok". In 1924, Vimala became the chief abbot of [[Pikara Monastery]]. He began to give sermons focusing on [[abhidharma|abhidhamma]] and teaching vipassana meditation. He attained Nirvana by practicing meditation for four years and became an Arhat. Then, he disseminated his method to the pupils for attaining Nirvana. He focused on the insight learning of the dynamic nature of mind and materials in his teaching. His teaching audio recordings are still available and learnt by Myanmar Buddhists to learn meditation methods. ==Legacy== U Vimala established the Mogok tradition of [[vipassana]] meditation, which is independent of the meditation traditions established by his Burmese predecessors, [[Ledi Sayadaw]] and [[Mahasi Sayadaw]].{{cite book|last=Crosby|first=Kate|title=Theravada Buddhism: Continuity, Diversity, and Identity|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|date=2013|isbn=9781118323298}} U Vimala stressed dependent origination and cittanupassana as part of meditation practice. There are currently over 300 meditation centers in Burma that teach his form of meditation. ==See also== *[[Buddhism]] *[[Theravada]] *[[Vipassanā]] ==References== {{reflist}} == Further reading == * ''Seeking the Heart of Wisdom: The Path of Insight Meditation''. '''Yekutiel ben Yehudah Leib Gordon''' ({{lang-he|יקותיאל גורדון}}; died after 1742) was a [[Kabbalah|Kabbalist]] and [[physician]] from [[Vilnius|Vilna]], and one of the main disciples of [[Rabbi]] [[Moshe Chaim Luzzatto]] (1707–1746). As such, he was one of the main conduits of Luzzatto's teachings from [[Padua]] to Eastern Europe.
Gordon came to [[Italy]] in order to study [[medicine]] at the [[University of Padua]]. It is there that he met Luzzatto, under whom he learned [[Torah]] and [[Kabbalah]]. He considered leaving his medical studies in order to dedicate himself to the study of Kabbalah; however, Luzzatto urged him not to; he insisted that his ''maggid'' or mystical teacher wished for Gordon to be successful in both areas.
Gordon was thus unwittingly the initial source of publicity of Luzzatto's ''maggid'': he wrote an account to his teacher in Vilna, thus initiating much of the controversy that surrounded Luzzatto. While he was greatly pained by this matter, the ''maggid'' insisted that these developments were heaven-sent.
Gordon was one of the [[transcription (linguistics)|transcribe]]rs of Luzzatto's writings. Following Luzzatto's death and the dissolution of his followers, Gordon returned to [[Poland]], where he established a group of his own which separated itself from the general community and adopted its own dress.

{{use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{use Indian English|date=March 2018}} {{Italics title |string=Ākāśa}} {{About|one of the six ''[[dravya]]s'' in Jainism|the Hindu and Buddhist term Ākāśa referring to æther or space|Ākāśa}} {{refimprove|date=March 2018}} {{Jainism}} '''''Ākāśa''''' is [[space]] in the [[Jainism|Jain]] conception of the [[Jain cosmology|cosmos]]. Akash is one of the six ''[[Dravya (Jainism)|dravya]]s'' (substances) and it accommodates<ref>Uttaradhyan sutra, Ch. 28</ref> the other five, namely sentient beings or souls (''[[Jīva (Jainism)|jīva]]''), non-sentient substance or matter (''[[pudgala]]''), principle of motion (''[[Dharma (Jainism)|dharma]]''), the principle of rest (''[[adharma]]'') and time (''[[kāla (time)|kāla]]'')
Akasha provides the space for other substances.<ref>http://nirgranth.in/6-dravya/</ref> Akasha does not act as an obstruction. There are two types of Ākāśa: Lokakasha and Alokakasha. Alokakasha is beyond the Lokakasha and is empty; it has no other substance. <ref>http://www.jainbelief.com/PPOJ/10.htm</ref>
<ref>http://www.jainsamaj.org/content.php?url=Jainism_-_Jain_Cosmology:-_By</ref>
== Etymology == Ākāśa is a compound word of Sanskrit language, wherein "ā" refers to "towards" and "kāśa" refers "to be visible or to appear".<ref>http://www.herenow4u.net/index.php?id=73983</ref> Thus, Akasha is the subtle “background” against which everything in the material universe becomes perceptible.{{sfn|Yogananda|2007|p=867}}
== Attributes == Space provides room to all other substances of the universe. The characteristic of space is to give room to or accommodate the other substances. The special feature of space is that it is not restricted to the universe like other substances but extends beyond the universe to the non-universe.
Its qualities are as follows:<ref>https://sites.fas.harvard.edu/~pluralsm/affiliates/jainism/jainedu/6dravya.htm</ref> *Provides room to soul, matter, medium of motion, and medium of rest *Pervades everywhere (infinite) *Supports everything and thus it is self supported *Have no form, color, taste, smell, and touch *Does not perform any active action (inactive) *Provides accommodation to soul and matter of their actions *Is one and whole
Sky and space both are different. We can see the sky because it is modification of the [[Pudgala]] whereas space is invisible.<ref>http://www.jainpushp.org/munishriji/ss-5-seven-tattava.htm</ref>
== Types of Akasha == [[File:Jain universe.JPG|thumb|300px|Structure of Universe according to the Jain scriptures.]]
Space substance is only one substance and as such it is indivisible (akhand).<ref>http://www.atmadharma.com/shastras/laghujainsiddhant_eng_txt/index.html</ref> However, universe (lokakasha) and non-universe (alokakasha) are considered its two divisions. Space is divided into two parts: *Lokakas - Where medium of motion and rest substances exist *Alokakas - The remaining space, which is empty and void. The dimension of Lokakasha is fourteen ''rajlok'' or ''rajju'', however Alokakasha is [[infinity|infinite]].<ref>https://sites.fas.harvard.edu/~pluralsm/affiliates/jainism/jainedu/6dravya.htm</ref>
=== Lokakasha=== That portion of space in which all the substances are found is called the universe (lokakash). There are three types of Lokakasha; a) Urdhwa Lok, where beings of higher qualities than us live (Siddha Lok where liberated souls stay is at the top of Urdhwalok), b) Madhya Lok - where human beings and other creatures live, and c) Adho Lok, where the inmates of hell live (it has seven layers).
At the summit of the ''lokākāśa'' is the ''[[Siddhashila]]'' (abode of the liberated souls).<ref>Sharma, C. (1997). ''A Critical Survey of Indian Philosophy'', Delhi: Motilal Banarsidass, {{ISBN|81-208-0365-5}}, p.64</ref>
The ''dharma'' & ''adharma'' ''dravyas'' are present only in ''Lokakasha'' and that is why ''jiva'' and ''pudgal'' are also there in the ''Lokakasha'' only.<ref>http://jainascience.blogspot.in/2007/12/six-substancesdravyas-in-jain.html</ref>
<ref>http://mangitungi.org/JainismNScience.aspx</ref>
=== Alokakasha === The (empty) infinite space outside the universe is called the non-universe (alokakash). In the non-universe, space alone exists without the other five substances. Actually in non-universe there is nothing but space.<ref>https://www.jainbooks/firstep-1/dravya.htm</ref>
Alokakash is perceptible only to the omniscient.
